technical-data.invention-title: VORRICHTUNGEN, ERFASSUNGSSCHALTUNGEN UND VERFAHREN ZUR KOMPENSATION EINER WORTLEITUNGSSPANNUNGSERHÖHUNG
APPARATUSES, SENSE CIRCUITS, AND METHODS FOR COMPENSATING FOR A WORDLINE VOLTAGE INCREASE
APPAREILS, CIRCUITS DE DÉTECTION ET PROCÉDÉS POUR COMPENSER UNE AUGMENTATION DE TENSION DE LIGNE DE MOT

abstract.p: Apparatuses, sense circuits, and methods for compensating for a voltage increase on a wordline in a memory is described. An example apparatus includes a bitline, a memory cell coupled to the bitline, a selector device coupled to the memory cell, a wordline coupled to the selector device, and a wordline driver coupled to the wordline. The apparatus further includes a model wordline circuit configured to model an impedance of the wordline and an impedance of the wordline driver, and a sense circuit coupled to the bitline and to the model wordline circuit. The sense circuit is configured to sense a state of the memory cell based on a cell current and provide a sense signal indicating a state of the memory cell. The sense circuit is further configured to adjust a bitline voltage responsive to an increase in wordline voltage as modeled by the model wordline circuit.

Apparatuses, sense circuits, and methods for compensating for a voltage increase on a wordline in a memory is described. An example apparatus includes a bitline, a memory cell coupled to the bitline, a selector device coupled to the memory cell, a wordline coupled to the selector device, and a wordline driver coupled to the wordline. The apparatus further includes a model wordline circuit configured to model an impedance of the wordline and an impedance of the wordline driver, and a sense circuit coupled to the bitline and to the model wordline circuit. The sense circuit is configured to sense a state of the memory cell based on a cell current and provide a sense signal indicating a state of the memory cell. The sense circuit is further configured to adjust a bitline voltage responsive to an increase in wordline voltage as modeled by the model wordline circuit.

L'invention concerne des appareils, des circuits de détection et des procédés qui permettent de compenser une augmentation de tension sur une ligne de mot dans une mémoire. Un appareil illustratif comprend une ligne de bits, une cellule de mémoire couplée à la ligne de bits, un dispositif sélecteur couplé à la cellule de mémoire, une ligne de mot couplée au dispositif sélecteur et un circuit d'attaque de ligne de mot couplé à la ligne de mot. L'appareil comprend en outre un circuit de ligne de mot modèle, configuré pour modéliser une impédance de la ligne de mot et une impédance du circuit d'attaque de ligne de mot, et un circuit de détection couplé à la ligne de bits et au circuit de ligne de mot modèle. Le circuit de détection est configuré pour détecter l'état de la cellule de mémoire sur la base d'un courant de cellule et pour fournir un signal de détection indiquant l'état de la cellule de mémoire. Le circuit de détection est en plus configuré pour régler une tension de ligne de bits en réponse à une augmentation de la tension de ligne de mot modélisée par le circuit de ligne de mot modèle.

L'invention concerne des appareils, des circuits de détection et des procédés qui permettent de compenser une augmentation de tension sur une ligne de mot dans une mémoire. Un appareil illustratif comprend une ligne de bits, une cellule de mémoire couplée à la ligne de bits, un dispositif sélecteur couplé à la cellule de mémoire, une ligne de mot couplée au dispositif sélecteur et un circuit d'attaque de ligne de mot couplé à la ligne de mot. L'appareil comprend en outre un circuit de ligne de mot modèle, configuré pour modéliser une impédance de la ligne de mot et une impédance du circuit d'attaque de ligne de mot, et un circuit de détection couplé à la ligne de bits et au circuit de ligne de mot modèle. Le circuit de détection est configuré pour détecter l'état de la cellule de mémoire sur la base d'un courant de cellule et pour fournir un signal de détection indiquant l'état de la cellule de mémoire. Le circuit de détection est en plus configuré pour régler une tension de ligne de bits en réponse à une augmentation de la tension de ligne de mot modélisée par le circuit de ligne de mot modèle.

description.p: APPARATUSES, SENSE CIRCUITS, AND METHODS FOR COMPENSATING
FOR A WORDLINE VOLTAGE INCREASE
TECHNICAL FIELD

{'0001. j Em odiments of the inventio relate generall to electronic memories., d more particularly, in one or more of the illustrated embodiments, to compensating for increasing wordline voltage caused by leakage currents from memory cell selectors.
DESCRIPTION OF RELATED ART

{'0002) Certain memory architectures are susceptible to current leakage from a bithne through a bipolar selector device to a wordline durin memory access operations. Current leakage through the bipolar selector device to the wordliae can lead to aa increased wordliae voltage, which may cause fluctuations in current of a sense signal provided on the hhime. That is, an increased wordline voltage may reduce the voltage margin to accurately read the sense signal used to sense the data, stored by a memory cell. As a result, the reduced voltage margin may lead to inaccurate reading of a memory cell.
SUMMARY

{'0003) Example apparatuses, sense circuits and methods are disclosed herein. An example apparatus may include a hiiline. a memory cell coupled to the bitltne, and a selector device coupled to the memory cell The example apparatus may -further include a wordline coupled to a base of the bipolar selector device, and a wordline driver coupled to the wordliae. The example apparatus may further include a model wordliae circuit configured to model an impedance of the wordline and an impedance of -the wordline driver, and a sense circuit coupled to the bitlme and to the model wordline circuit The sense circuit may be configured to sense a state of the memory cell based on. a cell current, and to prov ide a sense signal indicating a state of the memory cell. The sense circuit may he further configured to adjust a bitli.se voltage responsive to an increase in wordline voltage as modeled by the model wordline circuit.

I
£0004) An ample seme circuit ma include an amplifier configured to provide a first signal and a second si nal. The, first signal and the second signal may be based on a bitline voltage and a sense reference voltage adjusted based on an i mpedance of at least portion of a wordline. The birl ne voltage may be received at a first input and the sense reference voliage way be adjusted based on an impedance of at least a portion of a wordline is received at a second input. The first signal may be fed back to the second input. The example sense circuit may further include a comparator configured to provide an outpiit signal indicating a sfcate of a .memory cell based on a voltage of the second signal and the bitline voltage*.

[øøø§] A example method ma include prechargiug a bit ine of the memory device to a precharge voltage,. The the precharge voltage may be based on a sense reference voltage adjusted based on an increase in a wofd!me voltage. The example method may further include enabling a selector device coupled to the bitline. Enabling of the bipolar device may cause a cell current to flow through the bitline. The example method may further .include determining a state of a memory cell coupled to the bitline based on a bitline voltage resulting fern the cell current.

|0006] Another example method may include receiving a sense reference voltage at a model wordline circuit. The impedance of the model wordline circuit may be approximately equal to an impedance of at least a portion of a wordline and wordline driver of a memory array. The another example method may further include providing a mode! cell current through the model wordline circuit, and adjusting the sense reference voltage based on the sense reference voltage plus a voltage based on the model cell current .flowing through the model wordline circuit.
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE DRAWINGS

JW07] FIG, 1 is a block diagram of a particular illustrative embodiment of an apparatus including a model wordline circuit and sense circuit;
(0008] FIG. 2 is a block diagram of a particular illustrative embodiment of an apparatus including a model ordline circuit and sense circuit;
[0009] FIG. 3 is a block diagram of a particular illustraiive embodiment of a dual output amplifier circuit;
{0810] FIG. 4 is a block diagram of a particular illustrative embodiment of a model wordihie driver; and
(0011] FIG, 5 is a block diagram of a memor including a model wordline circuit and sense circuit according to an embodiment of the disclosure.
DETAILED DESCRIPTION

[0012] Certain details are set forth below to provide a sufficient understanding of embodiments of the disclosure. However, it will be clear to one having skill in the art that embodiments of the disclosure may be practiced without these particular details. Moreover., the particular embodiments of die present disclosure described herein are provided by way of example and should not be used to limit the scope of the disclosure to these particular embodiments,

[0013] Referring to FIG. !., a particular illustrative embodiment of an apparatus including a model wordline circuit and sense circuit is disclosed and generally designated 100, The apparatus may be an integrated circuit, a memory device, a memory system, an electronic device or system,, a smart phone, a tablet, a computer, a server, etc. The apparatus 100 may compensate for a voltage increase on the worclline during a read operation due to current leakage through a selector device, such as a bipolar selector device. The apparatus 100 may include a plurality ophid nes 124(0~N), A illustrated in FIG. 1 , each bitSine 124(0-N) is coupled to a respective memory cell ! 30(0-N) that is coupled in series with a respective selector device 14Q(Q~N). The selector devices M0(0~M) are illustrated in FIG, I as PNP bipolar junction transistors.:. Other types of circuits may he used for the selector devices 140(0-M) without departing from, the scope of the present disclosure. Although
FIG. 1 illustrates one memory cell O(0-N) for each bitlme 124(0-M), a plurality of memory cells may be coupled to each bitline. Embodiments of the disclosure may be used with bitlines coupled to one or more memory cells, A base of each selector device ! 40{0-N) may be coupled to a wordline 160. The apparatus 100 may farther include a lural ty of sense circuits !20(0-N) that are each configured to sense a respective cell current iCELLfO-N) flowing through the respective bitline 124(0-N). The respective iCBLL(0~N) current indicates state of the corresponding memory cell. 130(0-N). Each of the sense circuits 120{0-N) compares the respective ICELL<0-N) current with current generated based on a reference voltage SVREF(0~ ). The SVllE 'fO- ) voltage may be adjusted based on an impedance of a wordline and wordline driver, 1¾e SV' EF(O- ) voltage may 'be adjusted by a model wordline circuit 110.

001 } The model wordline circuit 1 10 may include a firs model wordline driver 112 and a second model wordline driver 1 14, each coupled to a model wordline 1 18, The first model wordline driver 1 1.2 and the second model wordline driver 1.1.4 may each model at least one of a first wordline driver and a second wordline driver (e.g., wordline drivers 150 and 152) to drive a voltage on the model wordline 1 18. The model, wordline 1 IS may he of a similar material and/or have similar electrical characteristics of the wordline 160, The model wordline resistance components .! .!6(0-N) may model impedance along at least a portion of the wordline 160.

'0015} Each of the sense circuits 120(0-' > may 'be coupled t a respecti ve bitlme 124(0-N} and may be configured to may drive the respective ICELL(O-N) current along the respective bitline 1 24(0~N). Further, each of the sense circuits I2G(0-'N) ma be coupled to the model wordline circuit 1 10 and may be configured to provide a respective model sense current i€ELLM(0-N} to the model wordline 1 18. Each of the sense circuits 120(O-N) may also provide a respective sense out signal SENSE OUT(O-N) which may indicate the state of the respective memory cell 130(0- }..

00.16] Each of the .memory cells 130(0~N) may be configured to store data, hi an embodiment, each of the memory cells 130(0-N) may include a phase change memory
material. The phase change memory material may he in one of at least two states, for example, aa unprogrammed state a id a programmed state. The phase change memory material may have a distinct impedance for each state. In aa embodiment, the phase change memory material may include a ehaicogenide alloy, such aa aa alloy of ermanium, antimony ard tellurium (GeShTe), called GST. fOOIT} In operation, during a memory access operation, each of the sense circuit 12O(0-M) may precharge each respective bittine 124(0- ) to the SV EF voltage prior sensing. In addition, the first wordline driver 150 and the second wordliiie driver 152 drive an memory access voltage along the wordline 160 to enable each of the selector device I4O(0-M}. When a. selector device 1 0(0-N) is enabled, die corresponding ICELL(O-N) current flows through the respective memory cell 130(0-N), The magnitude of the l€ELL(0-N) current is based on the state (e.g., impedance) of the respective memory cell 130(0- ), Based on the respective ICELL(O-N) current, each of the sense circuits 120(0-N) may provide a respective SENSE 0UT(0-!si) signal, A magnitude of the SENSE OOT{0- ) signal .indicates the state of the respective memory cell 130C0-NK and, accordingly, may indicate a data value stored by the respecti e memory cell 13 (0-N}. 00iS] The selector devices 140(0-N) may leak current through the bases to the worc!!me

160. For example, FIG. 1 depicts cell current ICELL L(0~N) and cell current ICELL R(O-N) leaking through the base of a selector device 140(O- } to the wordline 160. live current leakage causes an increase in voltage of the wordline because the wordline 1 0, the first wordline driver 150, and the second wordline driver 152 have n -aero impedances. The wordline voltage increase may reduce base-emitter voltages VEB of the selector devices I40C0-N). As a consequence, the ICELL(O-N) current for each sense circuit 120(0-N) may be reduced. The magnitude of current leakage through the base of each selector device 140(0*N) may depend on a gain {13} of the selector device I40(0-N), an impedance of the wordline 160, m impedance of the first wordline driver 150 and the second wordline driver 152, and a. state of the corresponding memory cell 130{0»N .
|001 ) $& some embodiments, compensation for Increase wordlme voltage resulting from the leakage current may be dynamically adjusted and may be based oa several dependencies. For xam le, each of the sense circuits .! 20(0~N) may use the model, wordiine circuit .1 10 to compensate for the increased wordiine voltage by modelin the increase in erdlme voltage, and compensating (e.g., increasing) the SVREP voltage by an amount that is based on the voltage increase. Compensating the SVREF voltage may increase the ICELL currents,, and, thus improve the voltage margin for sensing the ICELL. currents.

£0020] To model the increase in wordiine voltage, each of the sense circuits 120(0-N) drives a respective model cell current ICELL (O- ) through the model wordiine 1 18 and through at least one of the first wordiine driver 1 12 and the second wordiine driver ! 14, similar to the ICELL current of the wordiine 160. For example, the ICELL (i)- ) current may be divided into two components, for example, model cell current ICELL ML(O-N) and mode! cell current ICELL MRfC N}, Responsive to tire ICELL ()> ) current drives through the model wordiine 1 18 and through at least one of the first model wordiine drive? 1 12 and the second mode! wordiine driver 1 1 b a corresponding sense circuit 120{0~N), the corresponding sense circuit 120(0~N) may use a voltage differential along the model, wordiine 1 18 (e.g., based on the model wordiine resistance 1 ,1 (0-N) and an impedance of the first model wordiine driver 1 12 and the second model wordiine driver 1 14} to adjust (e.g., increase) the corresponding S VREf (0-N) voltage. Responsive to adjustment of the corresponding SVKEF(0-N) voltage by the corresponding sense circuit J 2O(0-N), the corresponding ICELL(0~N) current along the respective itline 124(0-N) is adjusted (e.g., increased). Increasing, for example, the iCELL(O-N) current (responsive to the adjusted corresponding SVREP(0«N)} to compensate for the increased wordiine voltage may increase the accuracy of the data sensed from a memory ceil B§(§-M} during a read operation, 0021] While FIG. 1. depicts the apparatus 100 with at least three bitilnes S 24(0»N), the apparatus 100 may include any number of bitlines. Similarly, although one wordiine Ϊ60,
and associated wordline drivers 150, 152, and selector devices 140(0-M) are illustrated in PIG.l , the apparatus may include any number of wordlines, and associated wordline drivers, and selector devices. Also, each of the model wordline resistance components I ! 6(0-N) ma represent impedance of a portion of the model wordline 1 18. Compensating for increased word! me voltage, which may cause a decrease in the sense signal, by using the model wordline circuit 110 may increase the voltage margin for sensing the iCELL currents, and improve sense accuracy of each of the sense circuits ! 20{0-N). The sense Circuits. I 20(0-N), in conjunction with the model wordline circuit 10, may provide a dynamic compensation solution by using a model of the respective iCELL(O- ) current through the bitike to determine the increased curren Referring to FIG, 2, a particula illustrative embodiment of a apparatus including a model wordline circuit and sense circuit is disclosed and generally designated 200. The apparatus 200 may represent a single sense circuit for a single bltline. The apparatus 200 may include a sense circuit 220 that uses a wordline model circuit 210 to provide an adjusted sense reference voltage signal SV EFM to compensate for increased wo.rdl.ine voltage which may be caused by current leakage along the wordline. The sense circuit 220 is coupled to a memory cell 230 though a bltline 226, An impedance of the bitiine is represented by bltline load 280. A selector device 240, such as a bipolar selector device, is coupled to the memo y cell 230 and is configured to select the memory cell 230 for memory access responsive to being activated by a wordline coupled to a base of the selector device 240. The wordline and associated wordline driver are represented by wordline and d«ver(s) 250 as impedances RWLDR and R L, The wofdliae model circuit 210 includes a RWLDRM component and a RWLM resistive component to model the impedances RWLDR and RWL, respectively, of the wordline driver(s) and wordline 250. The RWLDRM component may model the RWLDR impedance and a gain (0) of die selector device 240. For example, an. impedance of the RWLDR component may be approximately equal to RWLDR (8-H), The RWLM resistive component may model the RWL impedance and the 8 gain of the bipolar device 240, For example, an impedance of
the WLM resistive component msy be approximately equal to W!.. (8^i). The R LDR impedance may .represent a word line driver impedance, such as an. impedance of at least one of the first wordline driver 150 and the second wordlme driver 1.52 of FIG. 1. The RWL impedance may present at least a portion of impedance of a wordlme, such as at least a portion of an. impedance of the wordline i 60 of FIG, ί ,

0024j The sense circuit 220 also provides an. sense output signal SE SEOUT based on a comparison between a voltage of an amplifier output signal A POUT and a bitline voltage VBL, The sense circuit 220 may include an amplifier 222 to provide die AMPOUT signal and further include a comparator 228 to perform the comparison. The model wordline circuit 210 may include at least a portion of the model wordline circuit ! 10 of FIG. 1 . The sense ircui 220 may include one of the sense circuits 120(Q~N) of FIG. 1. The memory cell 230 and the selector device 240 may include at least one of the memory ceils i30(0«.N) and the selector devices 140(0-N}, respectively, of FIG 1. The wordline and driver(s) 250 may include at least a portion of the first wordlme driver 150, the second, wordline driver 152 and the wordline 1.60 of FIG. I.
0025) The amplifier 222 may be a differential amplifier configured t receive the

SVREFM voltage from, the model wordline circuit 210 at a first input. The amplifier 222 may he further configured to receive a bitline voltage VBL at a second input. The amplifier 222 may produce tiie AMPOUT signal at a first output and an model amplifier output signal AMPOUT at a second output, each based on the first input and the second, input Th A POUTM signal may he fed back to fhe first input of the amplifier 222. in an embodiment, the AMPOUTM signal is approximately equal to the AMPOUT signal.

0026J The comparator 228 may be configured to receive the AMPOU signal at a first input and to rece ve the VBL voltage at a second input. The first input of the comparator 228 may be coupled to the second input of the comparator 228 via the hmtier circuit 224, The AMPOUT signal may be fed back to the bitline via the limiter circuit 224. In an embodimej.it, the Hmiter circuit 224 may include a diode pair coupled in parallel, with the diode DO having a forward direction from the first input to the second input and a diode Di
having a forward direction .from the second input to the first input, in an alternative embodiment, the Hinder circuit 224 may include a resistive component The limiter circuit 224 ma l mi a voltage differentia! between the first input and the second input. I» operation, a reference current IE.EF is provided to the bitline 226, The IREF current is a constant current provided to the hiiline during a read operation.. Based on the reference current, the bitline 226 is prccharged to approximately the SVREF voltage (e.g., the VBL voltage is approximately equal to the SVREF voltage) via the AMPOUT signal of the amplifier 222 provided to the bitline 226 through the DO diode of the limiter circuit 224. The SVREF voltage may be approximately equal to the SVREFM voltage. When the selector device 240 is enabled, an ICELL current, which may depend o the state of the memory cell and the IREF current,, begins to flo through the bitline 226, As the !CELL current Hows, current may leak through the base of the selector device 240 through the wordline and drivers) 250. The current leakage may cause an increase in. wordline voltage (e.g., near the base of the selector device 240), and consequently, may result in a reduction in read margin. The increase in wordline voltage ma be equivalent to a voltage SVA across a word line driver impedance RWL R, plus a voltage SVB across a word, line uripe dan ce R W L. The amplifier 222 provides an AMPOOTM signal, responsive to the increase in wordline voltage that causes a model cell current iCELLM to flow through the wordline model circuit 210, The !GELLM current flowing through the wordline model circuit 210 may cause a voltage of the SVREFM signal to change by the sum voltage of SVAM and SVB . The change in the SVREFM signal models the increase in wordline voltage due to the current leakage through the base of the selector device 240 (e.g., SVA*SVB), The amplifier 222 responds by providing an AM.POUT signal that adjusts the VBL voltage (through, the iirrsiier circuit 224) to compensate for the increased wordline voltage (e.g., VBL SVREF 4· SVA. + SVB). The comparator 228 may compare the voltage of the AMPOUT signal to the VBL voltage responsive to selection by the selector device 240 and
provide the SENSEOUT signal. The SENSE OUT signal may represent a state (e.g., impedance) of the memory cell 230.
0029) In an embodiment, the first input of the amplifier 222 is a non-inverting input.

Thus, feeding back the AMPOUTM s gnal to the first input of the amplifier 222 forms a positive feedback system. To prevent instability (e.g., oscillation) in the positive feedback sy t m, the RWLDRM impedance and/or the RWLM impedance may be adjusted to result in feedback gain of the positive feedback system of less than one. An. example of adjusting die model wo.rdl.me driver impedance is discussed further with reference to FIG. 4.

'0030} The sense circuit 220 could be replicated for a plurality of foitiiues in an array, such as the apparatus of claim I . Also as would be obvious to one of ordinary skill in the art, the RWL impedance and the RWLDR Impedance may vary for each MtUae based on a location along the wordline and variances in characteristics of each individual bipolar device 240,.

0031. J Referring to FIG. 3„ a particular illustrative embodiment of a dual output amplifier circuit is disclosed and generally designated 300, The dual output amplifier circuit 300 may include an amplifier 322, The amplifier 322 ma be configured to receive an adjusted sense reference voltage signal SVREFM from a model wordline circuit 310 at first Input and a it!ine voltage VBL at a second input. The amplifier 322 may also be configured to provide an amplifier output signal AMPOUT from a first output and an model amplifier output signal AMPOUTM from, a second output. The model wordline circuit 310 may include at least a portion of the model wordline circuit 1 10 of FIG. 1 , and/or the model wordline circuit 219 of FIG. 2. The amplifier 322 may include the amplifier 222 of FIG, 2, and may be included in the sense circuit 120 of FIG. Ί and/or the sense c rcuit 220 of FIG.
'0032} The amplifier 322 .may be a differential amplifier configured to receive the

SVREFM voltage from the model wordline circuit 310 at a gate of a second transistor 352
and a it.Htie voltage VBL at a gate of a fourth transistor 362 ami a gate of a sixth transistor 372. The amplifier 322 may be provide the AMPOUT signal at a first output node between a third transistor 360 and the fourth transistor 362 and the AMPOUTM signal at a second output node between a fifth transistor 370 and the sixth transistor 372, The AMPOUT and the AMPOUTM signals may each he based on the first input and the second input. The AMPOUTM signal may be fed back to the gate of the second transistor 352, in an embodiment, the AMPOUTM signal is approximately equal to the AMPOUT signal. 33J The second transistor 352 awl a first transistor 3.50 may form a first, current mirror circuit with the fourth transistor 362 and the third transistor 360. For example, the first transistor 350 coupled i scries with the second transistor 352. A source of the first transistor 350 is configured to receive first power source (e.g., a VCC power source) and a source of the second transistor 352 is configured to receive a second power source (e.g., a ground power source). A gate of the first transistor 350 is coupled to the drain of the second transistor 352. A gate of the second transistor 352 is configured to receive the SVREFM voltage that is adjusted by the model w'ordline circuit 310. A source of the third transistor 360 is configured to receive the first .power source and source of the fourth transistor 362 is configured to receive the second power source. A gate of the third transistor 360 is coupled to the gate of the first transistor 350 and a gate of the fourth transistor 362 is configured to receive the VBL voltage. The AMPOUT signal may he provided at a node 'between the third transistor 360 and the fourth transistor 362, The AMPOUTM signal is fed back to the gate of the second transistor 352. j Addition-ally, the second transistor 352 and a first transistor 350 may form a second current mirror circuit with the sixth transistor 372 and the fifth transistor 370. For example, the fifth transistor 370 is coupled in series with the sixth transistor 372. A source of the fift transistor 370 is configured to receive the first power source and a source of the sixth transistor 372 is configured to rece the second power source. A gate of the fifth transistor 370 is coupled to the gate of the first transistor 0 and a gate of the sixth
transistor 3?2 configured to receive the VRL voltage. The AMPOUT signal is provided at a node etween the fifth transistor 370 and the sixth transistor 372, I an. embodiment, the first current mirror circuit is nearly identical to the second current mirror circuit

(0035} As would be obvious to one ordinarily skilled in the art, the amplifier 322 could be implemented using other amplifier architectures, such as an amplifier using bipolar junction, transistors. The amplifier 322 may provide the AMPOUT signal and the A POUT signal having characteristics that attempt to equalize the VBL voltage received at the gate of the sixth transistor 372 and/or die fourth transistor 362 with die SV EFM voltage received at the gate of the second transistor 352.

('0036} Referring to FIG. 4, a particular illustrative embodiment of art model wordline driver is disclosed and generally designated model wordline driver 400. The model wordline driver 400 may be configured to model a wordline driver impedance. The model wordline driver 400 may he configured to receive a sense reference voltage signal SV EP and provide an output voltage VOUT. The model wordline driver 400 may include the first mode! wordline driver 112 and/or the second model wordline driver 1 14 of FIG, 1. The model wordline driver 400 may be included in the RWLDR component of the model wordline circuit 210 of FIG, 2, and/or the model wordline circuit 310 of FIG, 3,

|003 } The model wordline driver 400 may be follower circuit that includes a first transistor 43 and a second transistor 432 coupled in series, and further includes and a third transistor 440 and a fourth transistor 442 coupled in series, A drain of the first transistor 430 is coupled to a first power source (e.g., a VCC power sources via a first current regulator 420 and a drain of the second transistor 432 is coupled to a second power source (e.g., a ground power source) via a second current regulator 422, A gate of the first transistor 430 may be coupled to the drain of the first transistor 430. A gate of the second transistor 432 may be co u pled to t he dram of the second transistor 432,

(0038} A. drain, of the third transistor 440 is coupied to the first power source and a drain of the fourth transistor 442 is coupled to the second power source. A gate of the third
transistor 440 may be coupled to the gate of the first transistor 430. A. gate of the fourth transistor 442 may be coupled to the gate of the second transistor 432, An output resistance ROUT 450 may he coupled to a node between the third transistor 440 and the fourth transistor 442, and the VOUT voltage may be provided via the ROUT 450. The ROOT 450 may be configured to model an impedance at a output of a wordime driver, such as the wordime drivers 150 and 152 of FIG, 1 .
0059] In operation, the SVREF voltage is received at a node between the first transistor

430 and the second transistor 432, A current 11 along a path through the first transistor 430 and the second transistor 432 is controlled by a first current regulator 420 and a second current regulator 422. A current 12 flows along a path through the third transistor 440. A model cell current iCELLM flows through, the ROUT resistance 450 and into a node between the third transistor 440 and the fourth transistor 442. Thus, current including the current 12 plus the ICELLM current flows through the fourth transistor 442. The current II is adjusted to control, the current flowing through the fourth transistor 442. A voltage differential between the SVREF voltage and the VOUT voltage may be indicative of an apparent resistance through the fourth transistor 442 that models a impedance associated with a word line driver.
'0040} The second current regulator 422 may he implemented using other voltage control circuits or adjustable resistance circuits to model the resistance of the word line driver.

0041] FIG. 5 illustrates a memory 500 according to an embodiment of the present invention. The memory 500 includes a memory array 530 with a plurality of memory cells. The memory cells may be non-volatile memory cells, such as NAKD flash ceils, phase change memory cells, or may generally be any type of memory cells,

#042} Command signals, address signals and write data signals may be provided to the memory 500 as sets of sequential input/output ("I/O") signals transmitted through an I/O bus 528. Similarly, read data signals may be provided from the memor 500 through the I/O bus 528. The I/O bus 528 is connected to an I/O control unit 520 that routes the
si nals between the I/O bus 528 and an internal data bos 522, an internal address bus 524, and an internal com and, bus 526. The memory 500 also includes a control logic unit 510 that receives a number of control signals either externally or through the command bus 526 to control the operation of the memor 500. 0043] The address bus 524 applies block-row address signals to a row decoder 540 and column address signals to a column decoder 550. The row decoder 540 and column decoder 550 may be used to select blocks of memory or memory cells for memory operations, for example, read, program, and erase operations. The column decode 550 may enable write data signals to be applied to columns of memory corresponding to the column address signals and allow read data signals to be coupled from columns corresponding to the column address signals.

I'00 4'l in response to the memory commands decoded by the control logic unit 510, the memory cells in the array 530 are read, programmed, or erased. Read, program, and erase circuits 568 coupled to the memory array 530 receive control signals from the control logic unit 5.10 and include current generators for generating various reference currents for read, program and erase operations. The read, program and erase circuits 568 may be coupled to a model wordline circuit 525. The model wordline circuit 525 may include the model wordline circuit 1 10 of FIG, 1 , the model wordline circuit 210 of FIG. 2, the model wordline circuit 310 of FIG, 3. the model wordline driver 400 of FIG, 4 and/or any combination thereof. For example, the model wordline circuit 525 may be configured to compensate tor current leakage along a wordline by modeling corresponding impedance of a wordline and a wordline driver to increase a corresponding cell current flowing through a memory cell used a read operation. The read, program and erase circuits 568 may include the sense circuit 120(0~N) of F.IG. I , the sense circuit 220 of FIG. 2, the amplifier 322 of FIG. 3, and/or any combination thereof In addition to the signal Sine drivers in the row decoder 540 and/or column decoder 550, one or more of the voltage generators or other read, program, and erase circuits 568 may also include signal line drivers.
(M SJ After the ro address signals have been -applied t the address bus 524, the I/O control unit 520 routes write data signals to a cache register 570, The write data signals are stored in the cache register 570 in successive sets each having sixe corresponding to the width of the I/O bos 528. The cache register 570 sequentially stores the sets of write data signals for an entire row or page of memory cells in the array 530. All of the stored write data signals are then used to program a ro or page of memory cells in the array 530 selected by the block-row address coupled through the address bus 524. In. a similar manner, during a read operation, data, signals from a row or block of memory cells selected by the block-row address coupled through the address bus 524 are stored in a data register 5 SO. Sets of data signals correspondi g in size to the width of the I/O bus 528 are then sequentially transferred through, the I/O control unit 520 from the data register 580 to the I O bus 528.

Various illustrative components, blocks, configurations, modules, circuits, arid steps have been described above generally in terms of thei functionality. Whether such functionality is implemented as hardware or processor executable instructions depends on the particular application and design constraints imposed on the overall system. Skilled artisans may implement the described fenctkxnality in varying ways for each particular application, but such implementation decisions should not be interpreted as causing a departure from the scope of the present disclosure.

0047] The previous description of the disclosed embodiments is provided to enable a perso skilled in the art to make or use the disclosed embodiments. Various modifications to these embodiments will be readily apparent to those skilled in the art, and the principles defined herein may be applied to other embodiments without departing f om the scope of the disclosure. embodiments s own h r hut is to be accorded the widest scope possible consistent with the principles and novel features as defined by the following claims.
